content:
I reviewed [redacted name] today who attended with his wife following recent admission to [redacted name] Hospital with increasing lower back pain and right-sided sciatica. He was diagnosed with metastatic prostate cancer in January 2024 following presentation with severe back pain and PSA of 125. Initial staging demonstrated a T3b prostate adenocarcinoma with Gleason 4+5=9 disease on biopsy, with extensive bone metastases particularly affecting the spine, pelvis, and several ribs. MRI spine in January showed epidural extension at T8 with mild cord compression, which was treated with emergency radiotherapy 20Gy in 5 fractions with good symptomatic benefit.

He commenced androgen deprivation therapy with Goserelin and Enzalutamide in February 2024, with initial good PSA response dropping to 45 by March. However, he has experienced progressive symptoms over the last 3 weeks with worsening back pain requiring escalation of analgesia, new onset right-sided sciatica, and increasing fatigue. His mobility has significantly deteriorated and he now requires a wheelchair for anything more than short distances. Recent blood tests show rising PSA to 156 and new onset anaemia with Hb 98.

On examination today, he appears notably more frail than at last review. Performance status has declined to ECOG 3. There is marked tenderness over the lower thoracic and lumbar spine with reduced range of movement. Neurological examination shows reduced power in right leg (4/5) with positive straight leg raise at 45 degrees. Given these concerning features, I have arranged urgent MRI spine and CT scan to assess disease status and exclude further cord compression.

In view of clear clinical and biochemical progression on first-line therapy, I have discussed changing treatment to Docetaxel chemotherapy. However, given his current performance status and symptoms, I feel we should defer this decision until we have imaging results and have improved his symptom control. I have therefore made the following arrangements:

1. Urgent MRI spine and CT chest/abdomen/pelvis to assess disease status
2. Referral to acute oncology for urgent assessment and consideration of admission for pain control
3. Referral to palliative care team for specialist input with pain management
4. Continue current Enzalutamide and Goserelin
5. Review in clinic next week with scan results to make definitive treatment plan

I have explained to [redacted name] and his wife that the situation has become more challenging and that we need to focus on improving his symptoms before considering further systemic therapy options.
